text:
What should you do if you
want to turn left at a junction
where pedestrians have
started to cross?

options.A: Give way to them
options.B: Sound your horn and proceed
options.C: Stop and wave at them to cross
options.D: Go around them, leaving plenty of room

explanation: You must give way to pedestrians who have started to cross. Pedestrians have priority when they are already crossing at junctions.

text:
Why should you check for
motorcyclists just before
turning right into a side
road?

options.A: They may be following you closely
options.B: They may be overtaking on your right
options.C: They may be emerging from the side road
options.D: They may be overtaking on your left

explanation: Motorcyclists may be overtaking on your right before you turn. Always check your right mirror and blind spot before turning right.

text:
Why is a toucan crossing
different from a puffin
crossing?

options.A: It's controlled by two flashing lights
options.B: Moped riders can use it
options.C: It's controlled by a traffic warden
options.D: Pedestrians and cyclists can use it together

explanation: A toucan crossing allows both pedestrians and cyclists to cross together. The name 'toucan' is a play on 'two can' cross.

text:
How will a school
crossing patrol signal you to
stop?

options.A: By displaying a 'stop' sign
options.B: By displaying a red light
options.C: By pointing to children waiting to cross
options.D: By giving you an arm signal

explanation: A school crossing patrol uses a 'STOP CHILDREN' sign on a pole to signal you to stop.

text:
Where would you see this
sign?

options.A: On the rear of a school bus or coach
options.B: In the window of a car taking children to school
options.C: At the side of the road
options.D: At playground areas

explanation: This sign is displayed on the rear of school buses or coaches to warn other drivers that children may be getting on or off.

text:
What does this sign
mean?

options.A: A route for cyclists only
options.B: A route for pedestrians only
options.C: No route for pedestrians and cyclists
options.D: A route for pedestrians and cyclists

explanation: This sign indicates a shared route for both pedestrians and cyclists to use together.

text:
You see a pedestrian
carrying a white stick that
also has a red band. What
does this mean?

options.A: They're deaf and blind
options.B: They have limited mobility
options.C: They're deaf
options.D: They're blind

explanation: A white stick with a red band indicates the person is deaf and blind (deafblind). A white stick alone means blind.

text:
What would you do if you
see older people crossing
the road ahead?

options.A: Be patient and allow them to cross in their own time
options.B: Tap the horn in case they're hard of hearing
options.C: Rev the engine to let them know that you're waiting
options.D: Wave them across so they know that you've seen them

explanation: Be patient and allow older people to cross in their own time. They may need more time to cross safely.

text:
What should you do
when you see an older
person about to cross the
road ahead?

options.A: Speed up to get past them quickly
options.B: Be careful; they may misjudge your speed
options.C: Stop and wave them across the road
options.D: Expect them to wait for you to pass

explanation: Be careful, as older pedestrians may misjudge your speed or how far away you are. Slow down and be prepared to stop.

text:
You're approaching a
roundabout. What should
you do if a cyclist ahead is
signalling to turn right?

options.A: Overtake on the right
options.B: Give a warning with your horn
options.C: Signal the cyclist to move across
options.D: Give the cyclist plenty of room

explanation: Give the cyclist plenty of room. Cyclists can signal and take a position in the centre of the lane when turning right at roundabouts.

text:
Which vehicle should
you allow extra room as you
overtake them?

options.A: Road-sweeper
options.B: Tractor
options.C: Bicycle
options.D: Lorry

explanation: Be patient and stay behind the cyclist. Don't overtake just before they turn left, as you may cut across their path.

text:
Why should you look
carefully for motorcyclists
and cyclists at junctions?

options.A: They may want to turn into the side road
options.B: They might not see you turn
options.C: They're harder to see
options.D: They may slow down to let you turn

explanation: Motorcycles have a smaller profile and can be hidden in blind spots. Check mirrors carefully and look out for them.

text:
You're waiting to come
out of a side road. Why
should you look carefully for
motorcycles?

options.A: Motorcycles have right of way
options.B: Motorcycles are usually faster than cars
options.C: Police patrols often use motorcycles
options.D: Motorcycles can easily be hidden behind obstructions

explanation: Move back to reduce the intimidation. Following too closely can make vulnerable road users feel pressured and unsafe.

text:
Why do motorcyclists
use dipped headlights in
daylight?

options.A: So that the rider can be seen more easily
options.B: To stop the battery overcharging
options.C: To improve the rider’s vision
options.D: The rider is inviting you to proceed

explanation: Be aware that the driver may not have seen you. The driver's view may be obscured by parked vehicles.

text:
Why do motorcyclists
often look round over their
right shoulder just before
turning right?

options.A: It helps them balance as they turn
options.B: To listen for traffic behind them
options.C: To check for traffic in their blind area
options.D: Motorcycles don't have mirrors

explanation: Hold back and allow the cyclist to proceed first. Squeezing past creates unnecessary danger.

text: Which is the most vulnerable road user?

options.A: Motorcyclist
options.B: Lorry driver
options.C: Tractor driver
options.D: Car driver

explanation: Allow extra room in case they wobble. Children and less experienced cyclists may be unsteady or unpredictable.

text:
You're approaching a
roundabout. What should
you do if there are horses
being ridden in front of you?

options.A: Sound your horn as a warning
options.B: Accelerate past as quickly as possible
options.C: Give them plenty of room
options.D: Treat them like any other vehicle

explanation: Move over to give them room. Horse riders need space and can be easily startled by close-passing vehicles.

text:
As you approach a
pelican crossing, the lights
change to green. What
should you do if older
people are still crossing?

options.A: Flash your lights in case they haven't noticed you
options.B: Wave them to cross as quickly as they can
options.C: Rev your engine to make them hurry
options.D: Wait patiently while they cross

explanation: Stay well back from the horse. Close following may frighten the horse and cause it to bolt or the rider to lose control.

text:
What action should you
take when you see flashing
amber lights under a school
warning sign?

options.A: Wait at the lights until they stop flashing
options.B: Reduce speed until you're clear of the area
options.C: Increase your speed to clear the area quickly
options.D: Keep up your speed and sound the horn

explanation: Allow them to cross in their own time. Never rush elderly pedestrians as they may need extra time.

text:
Why should these road
markings be kept clear?

options.A: To allow children to be picked up after school
options.B: To allow children to be dropped off at school
options.C: To allow teachers to park
options.D: To allow children to see and be seen when they're crossing the road

explanation: Pedestrians have priority at zebra crossings. You must stop and allow them to cross.

text:
Where would you see
this sign?

options.A: On a school bus
options.B: Near a school crossing
options.C: At a playground entrance
options.D: At a ‘pedestrians only’ area

explanation: Move to the left to increase the gap. Give motorcyclists plenty of space when they are alongside you.

text:
You're following two 
cyclists as they approach a roundabout in the left-hand lane. Where would you 
expect the cyclists to go?

options.A: Straight ahead
options.B: Any direction
options.C: Right
options.D: Left

explanation: Give way to them. Pedestrians who have started crossing have right of way.

text: You're travelling behind a moped. What should you do if you want to turn left a short distance ahead?

options.A: Overtake the moped before the junction
options.B: Pull alongside the moped and stay level until just before the junction
options.C: Sound your horn as a warning and pull in front of the moped
options.D: Stay behind until the moped has passed the junction

explanation: Be prepared to slow down and give way. The vehicle may be about to drop off passengers.

text:
You see a horse rider as you approach a roundabout.
What should you do if 
they're signalling right but keeping well to the left?

options.A: Stay well back
options.B: Proceed as normal
options.C: Keep close to them
options.D: Cut in front of them

explanation: Slow down and be ready to stop for pedestrians. They may cross suddenly without looking.

text:
How should you react to
inexperienced drivers?

options.A: Sound your horn to warn them of your presence
options.B: Be patient and prepare for them to react more slowly
options.C: Flash your headlights to indicate that it's safe for them to proceed
options.D: Overtake them as soon as possible

explanation: Remain behind until you can overtake safely. Don't rush past elderly pedestrians.

text:
What should you do
when you're following a
learner driver who stalls at a
junction?

options.A: Stay very close behind and flash your headlights
options.B: Immediately steer around them and drive on
options.C: Start to rev your engine if they take too long to restart
options.D: Be patient, as you expect them to make mistakes

explanation: The person is deaf and blind (deafblind). The red band on a white stick indicates this condition.

text: You're on a country road. What should you expect to see coming towards you on your side of the road?

options.A: Horse riders
options.B: Motorcycles
options.C: Bicycles
options.D: Pedestrians

explanation: Wave the pedestrians across. When you've stopped at a zebra crossing, you can gesture to confirm it's safe for them to cross.

text:
You're following a
cyclist. What should you do
when you wish to turn left a
short distance ahead?

options.A: Pull alongside the cyclist and stay level until after the junction
options.B: Hold back until the cyclist has passed the junction
options.C: Go around the cyclist on the junction
options.D: Overtake the cyclist before you reach the junction

explanation: The driver intends to turn left. The cyclist is signaling their intention to turn left.

text:
A horse rider is in the 
left-hand lane approaching a roundabout. Where should you expect the rider to go?

options.A: To the right
options.B: Straight ahead
options.C: To the left
options.D: In any direction

explanation: Slow down and give them time and space. Young children may do unpredictable things.

text:
Powered vehicles used by disabled people are small and can be hard to see.
What must they display if they're travelling on a dual carriageway?

options.A: Flashing amber beacon
options.B: Flashing red beacon
options.C: Flashing green beacon
options.D: Flashing blue beacon

explanation: Look out for animals being led, ridden or driven on the road. Rural roads often have animals.

text:
What does it mean when
a moving vehicle is showing
a flashing amber beacon?

options.A: The vehicle belongs to a school crossing patrol
options.B: The vehicle is slow moving
options.C: The vehicle is a doctor's car
options.D: The vehicle has broken down

explanation: Cyclists and motorcyclists. These are the most vulnerable in side winds due to their smaller mass and profile.

text:
What should you do
when you see these horse
riders in front?

options.A: Slow down and be ready to stop
options.B: Pull out to the middle of the road
options.C: Switch on your hazard warning lights
options.D: Give a right-turn signal

explanation: It will reduce your view ahead. Driving too close restricts your view of the road ahead.

text:
What's the purpose of
these road markings?

options.A: To ensure children can see and be seen when they're crossing the road
options.B: To enable parents to pick up or drop off children safely
options.C: To enable teachers to have clear access to the school
options.D: To ensure delivery vehicles have easy access to the school

explanation: Stay well back and don't rush them. Elderly pedestrians need time and shouldn't be pressured.

text:
What should you do if
the left-hand pavement is
closed due to street repairs?

options.A: Watch out for pedestrians walking in the road
options.B: Position close to the left- hand kerb
options.C: Speed up to get past the roadworks more quickly
options.D: Use your right-hand mirror more often

explanation: Move to the left and slow down. Give horse riders plenty of space as horses can be unpredictable.

text:
What should you do
when you're following a
motorcyclist along a road
that has a poor surface?

options.A: Follow closely so they can see you in their mirrors
options.B: Allow the same room as normal to avoid wasting road space
options.C: Allow extra room in case they swerve to avoid potholes
options.D: Overtake immediately to avoid delays

explanation: Give way to any pedestrians crossing. Pedestrians have priority when they're already crossing.

text:
What does this sign
mean?

options.A: No cycling
options.B: End of cycle route
options.C: Cycle parking only
options.D: Cycle route ahead

explanation: Slow down and be ready to stop. People may be crossing or about to cross near bus stops.

text:
You're approaching this roundabout. What should you do when a cyclist is 
keeping to the left while 
signalling to turn right?

options.A: Overtake them
options.B: Sound your horn
options.C: Allow them space to turn
options.D: Assume they're turning left

explanation: Drive slowly and carefully past them. Children can be unpredictable and may not see you.

text:
What should you do
when you're approaching
this crossing?

options.A: Stop and wave the pedestrians across
options.B: Continue unless the pedestrians step out
options.C: Prepare to slow down and stop
options.D: Speed up and pass by quickly

explanation: Ahead if you're approaching a school. This sign warns of a school crossing patrol ahead.

text:
What does it mean if you
see a pedestrian with a dog
that has a yellow or
burgundy coat?

options.A: The pedestrian is colour- blind
options.B: The pedestrian is a dog trainer
options.C: The pedestrian is an older person
options.D: The pedestrian is deaf

explanation: Slow down and be prepared to stop. Children can behave unpredictably near schools.

text:
Who may use toucan
crossings?

options.A: Only cyclists
options.B: Motorcyclists and cyclists
options.C: Cyclists and pedestrians
options.D: Motorcyclists and pedestrians

explanation: Give way to them. Pedestrians crossing at junctions have priority.

text:
This junction, controlled
by traffic lights, has a
marked area between two
stop lines. What's this for?

options.A: To allow taxis to position in front of other traffic
options.B: To allow people with disabilities to cross the road
options.C: To allow cyclists and pedestrians to cross the road together
options.D: To allow cyclists to position in front of other traffic

explanation: Leave plenty of room in case the cyclist wobbles. Cyclists may swerve to avoid drains, potholes, or debris.

text:
You're about to overtake
a cyclist. Why should you
leave them as much room as
you would give to a car?

options.A: The cyclist might have to make a left turn
options.B: The cyclist might speed up
options.C: The cyclist might get off their bicycle
options.D: The cyclist might be unsettled if you pass too near them

explanation: Be patient and give them time to cross. Never rush pedestrians, especially elderly ones.

text:
What should you do
when you're passing loose
sheep on the road?

options.A: Briefly sound your horn
options.B: Herd them to the side of the road
options.C: Pass quickly but quietly
options.D: Go very slowly

explanation: Move out early to give them extra room. Cyclists need space for safety.

text:
At night, what does it
mean if you see a pedestrian
wearing reflective clothing
and carrying a bright red
light?

options.A: You're approaching a traffic danger spot
options.B: You're approaching roadworks
options.C: You're approaching an organised walk
options.D: You're approaching a slow-moving vehicle

explanation: Slow down and be prepared to stop. Children may run into the road without looking.

text:
You’ve just passed your
driving test. How can you
reduce your risk of being
involved in a collision?

options.A: By always staying close to the vehicle in front
options.B: By never going over 40 mph
options.C: By staying in the left-hand lane on all roads
options.D: By taking further training

explanation: Wait for them to walk forward from the vehicle. They may be hidden by the parked vehicle.

text:
You're turning right from a main road into a side road. There's no oncoming traffic.
What should you do if 
pedestrians are standing on the pavement waiting to 
cross the side road?

options.A: Wait and give way to the pedestrians
options.B: Wave at the pedestrians, inviting them to cross the road
options.C: Turn in because the pedestrians are safe on the pavement
options.D: Sound your horn to alert the pedestrians to your presence

explanation: Wait for them to cross. Pedestrians who have started crossing have priority.

text:
You're travelling on a narrow section of road.
What should you do if a 
horse rider ahead is riding in the centre of the lane?

options.A: Get up close behind to encourage them to move aside
options.B: Sound your horn to alert them to your presence
options.C: Stay behind and allow them to ride in this position
options.D: Move across to the right and try to ease past them

explanation: Give signals before you change direction. This helps cyclists and others anticipate your movements.

text:
You’re about to overtake a cyclist on a road that has a 30 mph speed limit. How 
much room should you 
leave them as you overtake?

options.A: At least a car’s width
options.B: At least as much room as you would if you were overtaking a car
options.C: At least a car’s length
options.D: At least 2 car widths

explanation: Reduce your speed. Ice cream vans attract children who may run into the road without looking.

text:
You're turning left from a main road into a side road.
What should you do if 
there’s a pedestrian on the pavement waiting to cross the side road?

options.A: Flash your lights to encourage the pedestrian to cross
options.B: Wait and give way to the pedestrian
options.C: Sound your horn to let the pedestrian know you’re there
options.D: Carry on turning into the side road

explanation: Give way to them. Pedestrians crossing have priority.

text:
You want to reverse into a side road. What should 
you do if you aren't sure that the area behind your car is clear?

options.A: Get out and check
options.B: Carry on, assuming it's clear
options.C: Check the mirrors only
options.D: Look through the rear window only

explanation: Leave a safe gap between you and the cyclist. Give cyclists space to ride safely.

text:
You're about to reverse into a side road. What 
should you do if a 
pedestrian is waiting to 
cross behind your car?

options.A: Give way to the pedestrian
options.B: Wave to the pedestrian to stop
options.C: Sound your horn to warn the pedestrian
options.D: Reverse before the pedestrian starts to cross

explanation: Slow down until they've crossed. Pedestrians may cross from either side at these crossings.

text:
Which road users are
most difficult to see when
you're reversing your car?

options.A: Cyclists
options.B: Car drivers
options.C: Motorcyclists
options.D: Children

explanation: Give them plenty of room. Cyclists may need to swerve around obstacles.

text:
You want to turn right
from a junction. What should
you do if your view is
restricted by parked
vehicles?

options.A: Move out quickly, but be prepared to stop
options.B: Sound your horn and pull out if there's no reply
options.C: Stop, then move forward slowly until you have a clear view
options.D: Stop, get out and look along the main road to check

explanation: Children running out between vehicles. Parked cars can hide children who may run out suddenly.

text: You're at the front of a queue of traffic waiting to turn right into a side road. Why is it important to check your right mirror just before turning?

options.A: To check for emerging traffic
options.B: To look for pedestrians about to cross
options.C: To check for overtaking vehicles
options.D: To make sure the side road is clear

explanation: Stay behind the cyclist until it's safe to overtake. Don't squeeze past when there isn't enough room.

text:
You've driven up to a
pelican crossing. What must
you do while the amber light
is flashing?

options.A: Wait for the red-and-amber light before proceeding
options.B: Always wait for the green light before proceeding
options.C: Give way to any pedestrians on the crossing
options.D: Signal the pedestrian to cross

explanation: Slow down and be prepared to stop. The pedestrian may not be able to see or hear you approaching.

text:
You've stopped at a 
pelican crossing. What 
should you do if a disabled person is crossing slowly in front of you and the lights change to green?

options.A: Sound your horn
options.B: Wait for them to finish crossing
options.C: Drive in front of them
options.D: Edge forward slowly

explanation: Keep well back. Motorcycles can stop more quickly than cars in some conditions.

text:
You're driving past a line
of parked cars. What should
you do if a ball bounces out
into the road ahead?

options.A: Continue driving at the same speed and flash your headlights
options.B: Stop and wave the children across to fetch their ball
options.C: Slow down and be prepared to stop for children
options.D: Continue driving at the same speed and sound your horn

explanation: Be aware that the pedestrian may suddenly cross. They can't see you and may step into the road.

text:
You want to turn right
from a main road into a side
road. What should you do
just before turning?

options.A: Cancel your right-turn signal
options.B: Stop and set the parking brake
options.C: Check for traffic overtaking on your right
options.D: Select first gear

explanation: Give way to them. Pedestrians have priority when they're already crossing.

text:
You're driving in a slow-
moving queue of traffic.
What should you do just
before changing lane?

options.A: Change down to first gear
options.B: Sound the horn and flash your lights
options.C: Look for motorcyclists filtering through the traffic
options.D: Give a ‘slowing down’ arm signal

explanation: Slow down and prepare to stop. You should expect children near schools to act unpredictably.

text:
You're driving in town.
Why should you be careful if
there's a bus at a bus stop
on the other side of the
road?

options.A: The bus might move off suddenly
options.B: The bus might have broken down
options.C: The bus might remain stationary
options.D: Pedestrians might come from behind the bus

explanation: Give them plenty of space. Cyclists need room for safety and may need to move out to avoid hazards.

text:
How should you
overtake horse riders?

options.A: Use your horn just once to warn them
options.B: Drive up close and overtake as soon as possible
options.C: Speed isn't important but allow plenty of room
options.D: Drive slowly and leave plenty of room

explanation: Wait patiently behind them. Don't rush or pressure elderly pedestrians who are crossing.

text:
Why should you allow
extra room while overtaking
a motorcyclist on a windy
day?

options.A: The rider may be travelling faster than normal
options.B: The rider may turn off suddenly to get out of the wind
options.C: The rider may be blown in front of you
options.D: The rider may stop suddenly

explanation: Stay well back from the cyclist. This gives you better visibility and reaction time.

text:
Where should you take
particular care to look for
motorcyclists and cyclists?

options.A: At zebra crossings
options.B: On dual carriageways
options.C: At junctions
options.D: On one-way streets

explanation: Slow down and watch carefully. Children may not understand the dangers and could run into the road.

text:
The road outside this
school is marked with
yellow zigzag lines. What do
these lines mean?

options.A: You must stay with your vehicle if you park here
options.B: You may park on the lines when dropping off schoolchildren
options.C: You may park on the lines when picking up schoolchildren
options.D: You shouldn't wait or park your vehicle here

explanation: Yellow zigzag lines outside schools mean you must not wait or park your vehicle on them. This keeps the area clear for children's safety.

text:
You're driving past
parked cars. What should
you do if you see a bicycle
wheel sticking out between
the cars?

options.A: Slow down and wave the cyclist across
options.B: Slow down and be prepared to stop for a cyclist
options.C: Brake sharply and flash your headlights
options.D: Accelerate past quickly and sound your horn

explanation: Slow down and be prepared to stop for a cyclist. If you can see a bicycle wheel, a cyclist may be about to emerge from between the parked cars.

text:
You're driving at night.
What should you do if you're
dazzled by a vehicle behind
you?

options.A: Switch your rear lights on and off
options.B: Brake sharply to a stop
options.C: Set your mirror to the anti- dazzle position
options.D: Set your mirror to dazzle the other driver

explanation: Set your mirror to the anti-dazzle position. This will reduce the glare from headlights behind you without affecting your vision of the road ahead.

text:
You're driving towards a zebra crossing. What should you do if a person in a 
wheelchair is waiting to 
cross?

options.A: Continue on your way
options.B: Be prepared to stop
options.C: Wave to the person to wait
options.D: Wave to the person to cross Answers

explanation: Be prepared to stop. You must give way to anyone waiting to cross at a zebra crossing, including wheelchair users.
